body:
I have the same situation on one of my device for every folders. 
On another device, I have a "No Data" entry instead, without that JS error.

How do I reproduce this exactly?
The term directory and folder are intermingled, so it's not obvious to me what the directory tree needs to look like to repro this.

No data means there is no .stversions directory, or it's empty, or you have a filtering condition that results in no data.
Also, adding a breakpoint there, and printing the value of `$scope.restoreVersions.tree` and `$scope.restoreVersions.tree.filterNodes` would be interesting.

**No Data:**
I confirm that you're right about the No data part. Simple Versioning was seemingly activated for the folder but the .stfolder is empty. I don't remember activating versioning on that device so that may be an unrelated bug or oversight on my part.

**About the real JS bug:**
I really don't know how you could reproduce this. Is there any debug info I can send you that'd help? 
When I say Folder, I mean the Folders in the WebUI, the "shares" between the devices. Not a subdirectory inside of those.
Well, you can add a breakpoint in the js console, and print the value of those two things and let me know what it is.
Does the issue persist if you reload the page?

Sorry, I did not see the reply just before mine. 
I'm not really used to JS development; how do I add that breakpoint?

If I reload the page, the error appears again if I try to use the "Versions" button.

I think I managed to do it, if it's not what you were looking for, please provide me with some pointers.

I put a breakpoint on line 1967 of file /syncthing/core/syncthingController.js

`$scope.restoreVersions.tree: jQuery.fn.init`
`$scope.restoreVersions.tree.filterNodes: undefined`

This is what the file versions UI looks like right when the JS error pops up, it stays this way until closed.
![screenshot_2018-02-08_15-52-49](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11236668/35997669-2c4933f0-0ce8-11e8-8c68-1f240b86f2bb.png)

Is it reliably reproducible every time on the same machine or does it happen only sometimes?
If it happens always, what OS browser is it? Did you try a different browser?
All folders, all the time. Both on Chrome Version 63.0.3239.132 (Official Build) (64-bit) and Firefox 58.0.1.
But this is on a specific machine right? Is this Windows/Linux/macOS?

I'm accessing it from an Ubuntu 16.04 LTS machine and an Android 7 phone with the same result. Syncthing is running on a chromebox running an Ubuntu-based (14.04) distro called xbmcbuntu. The output of `uname -a` is `Linux <censored> 3.19.0-031900-generic #201502091451 SMP Mon Feb 9 14:52:52 UTC 2015 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux`.
This seems to be hanging; possibly related to #4901? Closing until a reproducer pops up or someone yells.

Err... why close a bug that's clearly affecting more than one person and that's not fixed? For me it stopped happening but only because I migrated that folder to gocryptfs and removed .stversions completely. But that doesn't mean this is solved or fixed.
I say there is no point in keeping something open if there is no reproducer, as it's not something we can fix, hence it's not actionable task we can close in the future
So I am not a fan of the interval hacks, and whoever decides to address this should probably somehow wait for angular/fancy tree to do it's thing before continuing with work.
I guess we could wait for a full digest cycle before setting up filters and what not.
Or make the tree hidden rather than not existant.
Take off, nuke from orbit, and rewrite the GUI in Dart or React or something.
Pr welcome.
I am sure dart fart and all others will have their own issues with their own lack of components such as trees.
So I guess this is a bonafide bug?
